reviewText: I did some research and found out that the episodes in this are kinda scooby doo all stars and scooby doo where are you. half the episodes ran as scooby doo where are you and then the rest where included the the scooby doo all star block. and then weren't re aired for over a decade. so there was actualy a scooby doo season 3 but it seems it wasn't totaly aired as season 3.

The packaging is obviously wrong.  "Scooby-Doo, Where Are You?" only ran for two seasons, 1969 and 1970.  In my opinion, it is by FAR the best Scooby-Doo series and I think it has the best theme song of all the series.  The third season didn't come until 1972 and then it was the hourlong "New Scooby-Doo Movies."  "The Scooby-Doo Show" came out in 1976 and as part of the "Scooby-Doo/Dynomutt Hour."  The 1978 series were the remaining shows from the "Scooby-Doo Show."  If anything, this set would contain those lost episodes.  Unfortunately, it's still too early for any information to come out but they should also include the episodes of the "New Scooby-Doo Movies" that were not included in the movies set.  Oh well, I'm sure it will be a great set because it is Scooby-Doo and it is still the PS (Pre-Scrappy) era.  So, that's why I'm giving it four stars mainly because I don't know which episodes they are and they don't have the right title but we shall see when the set is released.

I loved Scooby as a little girl and now my 4 year old daughter is obsessed with all things Scooby. We own the "Scooby Doo Where Are You?" Seasons 1 and 2 set and added this to our Scooby collection a few months ago for variety. Personally, we don't like the Scooby episodes that were made from the 1980s on, we love the classic episodes. I'm sure others have said this, but there was NOT a third season to the original series "Scooby Doo Where Are You?" The original series ran in 1969 and 1970 and then came the New Scooby Doo Movies (hour long episodes featuring a plethora of guest stars like Sonny and Cher, Mama Cass, The Globetrotters, etc.) in 1972-74. The episodes in this DVD set were episodes that aired in 1978 and 1979.

The episodes included in this set are on 2 discs (one double sided) and are: 1. Watch Out! The Willawaw 2. A Creepy Tangle in the Bermuda Triangle  3. A Scary Night With a Snow Beast Fright  4. To Switch a Witch  5. The Tar Monster  6. A Highland Fling with a Monstrous Thing  7. The Creepy Case of Old Iron Face  8. Jeepers, It's the Jaguaro!  9. Make a Beeline Away from That Feline  10. The Creepy Creature of Vulture's Claw  11. The Diabolical Disc Demon 12. Scooby's Chinese Fortune Kooky Caper  13. A Menace in Venice  14. Don't Go Near the Fortress of Fear  15. The Warlock of Wimbledon  16. The Beast is Awake in Bottomless Lake. One thing I didn't like was that the double sided disc doesn't have the sides labeled so it's hard to know which side will play using the track listing. These episodes feature the gang traveling around the world to visit friends and family in different countries and of course stumbling upon a mystery to solve.

Lastly, when the DVD box arrived, it looked worn around the edges like it had either been used or was sitting around for a very long time and had a tear in the cardboard. There's also a big sticker on the back of the box that can't be removed covering Scooby's face on the back cover. Inspired by such diverse material as radio's "I Love a Mystery" and television's "The Many Loves of Dobie Gillis," the cartoon series SCOOBY-DOO, WHERE ARE YOU was a smash hit for CBS in the late 1960s--and after running the original cartoons into the ground the network ordered a new set. Titled SCOOBY'S ALL STARS, this particular set of cartoons shows the Mystery Inc. gang in standard form: Fred with the ascot, Daphne in a purple dress, Velma in an orange sweatshirt and red mini-skirt, and Shaggy in a t-shirt and brown pants, all of them instantly recognizable. Unfortunately, nothing in this group of cartoons is up to the level of the originals.

The first series was sloppy at times, with the characters inconsistently drawn--one episode shows Velma with lipstick and freckles; another shows Fred with such a square jaw it looks like he could glass with the corners of it; and so on. But even so, the shows had a specific look and style, especially in terms of background art. SCOOBY'S ALL STARS are more consistent, but they aren't nearly as interesting in terms of art or animation, and the stories have a very loose quality and lots of comic filler. The episodes are watchable, at times even enjoyable, but if this were the only cartoons made, the series wouldn't be nearly so fondly recalled.

On the plus side, the elements are good, and this three disk collection includes a half-hour documentary on Hanna-Barbera. It doesn't offer much insight into Scooby-Doo and the gang, and one interviewer comments that Scooby-Doo was partly inspired by the t.v. series THE MOD SQUAD--which doesn't seem too likely given that THE MOD SQUAD and the original SCOOBY-DOO hit television screens at about the same time. Nonetheless, it offers interesting insight into the animation studio and it is a nice compliment to this otherwise ho-hom set. Recommended for hardcore fans, but others should probably leave it alone.

GFT, Amazon Reviewer

By the time 1978 rolled around, it was becoming apparent that the writers were simply running out of ideas for villains. Villains such as the Willawaw, the Tar Monster, the Diabolical Disc Demon and the Jaguaro simply don't resonate as well as those classic villains from 1969-70. However, let me make one thing clear: the 16 episodes on this two disc set aren't bad at all--just not what I consider classic material. Another thing is the packaging: discs overlapping each other in the case, thereby increasing the chances of scratching. Still, I recommend this set for all Scooby fans.

Freddy, Daphne, Velma, Shaggy and of course everyone's favorite talking dog Scooby Doo are back in this third season of Scooby Doo, Where Are You?, which is actually 16 episodes of The Scooby Doo Show which aired in the later part of the 70's. Unlike the first two seasons of Where Are You?, this show has Scoob and the gang trying to solve mysteries in a variety of new settings, like Japan, the mountains, even England.

Some fans didn't care for this new setting and I admit some aren't as good as the previous seasons, but that still doesn't take away from the classic feel of one of the all time goofiest and funniest cartoons around. I do admit I was not a fan of the added characters like Scoody Dum and Scrappy Doo, but thankfully they aren't featured a ton.

Disc 1

-Watch Out! The Willawaw: Here the gang is traveling by boat to visit Velma's uncle when they encounter a giant owl known as the Willawaw, so they try to find out what is behind the mysterious and screechy creature. Not a bad episode here.

-A Creepy Tangle In The Bermuda Triangle: Near the Bermuda Triangle the gang is on a boat partying, a storm hits damaging their boat, then they see the spaceship trap a weather plane, their boat crash lands on an island and they go to investigate the reasoning behind spaceships appearance. Decent one here.

-A Scary Night With A Snow Beast Fright: There's a giant snow creature/dinosaur that is wreaking havoc in the North Pole, which prompts the gang to come up and solve the mystery. Its a funny one at times and had some throwbacks to the other series, like Scooby and Shaggy dressing up to confuse the monster and the classic "Meddling kids" line is used.

-To Switch A Witch: On Halloween in the town of Old Salem a witch rises from the dead to terrorize the townsfolk, of course the kids and Scooby are coming to town visiting a friend that people claim is the witch. Looks like they must do their best to clear her name and capture the witch. Good one here.

-The Tar Monster: Up in the Turkish Mountains Scoob and Co. are visiting a professor who discovered an ancient city, so naturally scientific find brings a tar monster that tries to run off everyone, so its another mystery to be solved. Good one here.

-A Highland Fling With A Monstrous Thing: In Scotland, a friend of Velma's calls her to enlist her help in finding out the meaning behind an old highlander ghost and even the Lochness Monster appearing and running off the tourists of a castle she works at. Decent one here

Disc 2-Side A

-The Creepy Case Of Old Iron Face: While on a speed boat ride, the gang is chased by a man in a mask riding metal sharks, they get to the beach and find out about the legend of Skull Island and about the iron clad man they say earlier. Its an ok one.

-Jeepers, Its The Jaguaro!: In Brazil, their plane has to make an emergency landing in the jungles of the dreaded Jaguaro creature. So after Scooby and Shaggy run into it and with some headhunters after them, the natural plan is solve the mystery of the monster. This is an odd one to say the least.

-Make A Beeline Away From The Feline: Daphne's aunt transforms into a cat creature and is stealing jewelry for some reason, so once Scoob and his pals see this they try to find out why, clear the aunt's name and capture the culprit. Its a good one.

-The Creepy Creature of Vulture's Claw: On the way to visit a professor friend of Velma's the gang stumbles upon a mystery involving a weird mantis like creature. There's also a real estate agent who wants Velma's friend to sell his property to him, so guess what there's another investigation into the monster's motives. Not a bad one.

Disc 2-Side B

-The Diabolical Disc Demon: There's a weird phantom in a disco suit and kiss makeup that causes  the disappearance of a song writer, then the equipment in the studio malfunctions. So yet again the gang investigates the mystery of this phantom and try to find the missing song writer. An odd one.

-Scooby's Chinese Fortune Kooky Caper: While in China, the mystery machine gets a flat tire and the gang looks to stay the night at an old city inn when above all things a moon monster appears. So everyone tries to find out the meaning behind this creature. A decent one here. Side Note: If you don't laugh at the names of the people and the city they stay in then you're better than me, cause I kept laughing throughout.

-A Menace In Venice: In Italy (like the title didn't give that away), the gang is in town visiting a friend when they learn of a jewel thief named "The Ghostly Gondolier" and go on the search for clues to bust the criminal. A good one here.

-Don't Go Near The Fortress Of Fear: At a port in Puerto Rico they discover there's apparently some missing treasure that leads to an old fortress haunted by a ghost of an old general who likes to shoot of a cannon in the fortress. Well naturally Fred, Daphne and Velma are curious to explore while Shaggy and Scooby reluctantly join. A good one here.

-The Warlock Of Wimbledon: While on a run, two englishmen run into a goofy looking warlock who curses a tennis star to suffer a terrible fate. Once the gang runs into the tennis guy they decide to investigate this warlock curse. Good one here.

-The Beast Is Awake In Bottomless Lake: After taking a detour to avoid a flooded road, the gang ends up in Canada and finds out there's a beast at a camp resort (as if the title wasn't obvious enough). So after finding the resort deserted they decide to see whats behind this monster and the empty resort. Good one here.

The only special feature is a Q&A session where we find out how the artists and animators of the show reach each other internationally and how they manage to connect with the fans of the series.

The numbered Seasons of Scooby from 1969 to the late 80s are hard to keep track of. The 3rd Season of Scooby-Doo, Where are you is actually part of what was called Scooby's All-Star Laff-A-Lympics which featured several cartoons including "The Scooby-Doo Show" and "The Blue Falcon & Dynomutt" (who you might recognize from Harvey Birdman: Attorney at Law) between 1977-1978. Even though this series aired years after the Scooby-Doo/Dynomutt Hour, which is apparently considered a different series. Confused yet? This season features all the usual unlikely villians, utterly ludicrous last-minute plot explanations and borderline xenophobic cultural stereotypes. The Scooby-Doo formula works best in isolated, creepy surroundings, but this season puts the action into too many urban areas, which just don't seem right. Monsters appearing during a Wimbledon tennis match and in a recording studio are the lowest points of the season. The back of the box promotes the Season as "lost episodes". Well, I'm not sure where they were lost about but judging by the shocking quality of the prints I assume they were stored in someone's garage behind some old paint cans and a bag of cement gone hard. If you thought that the Tom and Jerry shorts from Warner looked bad then you ain't seen nothing yet. Pick it up cheap if you're a Scooby-Doo completist. Otherwise I'd suggest skipping to The 13 Ghosts of Scooby Doo: The Complete Series or A Pup Named Scooby-Doo: Complete 1st Season.

Some people like Scooby Doo, Where Are You seasons 1 and 2 because these episodes show the original campy yet not too creepy format. I love those, too, but even when I was a little kid I preferred the later, creepier episodes. The kind I could watch in a darkened room with delicious chills. Perhaps I love them even more because they are considered 'lost' episodes. I rarely saw them after the early 80's. The labeling of later episodes by season is certainly confusing, and it is appreciated that some reviewers have clarified things by categorizing the episodes. I had not read anything about 'Season 3' before finding it in a store, and was just thrilled because it would surely have all my favorite lost episodes on it. (It doesn't, but many of them are included). Most of us fans refer to an episode by its villain, and this DVD has some great ones: the Cat Creature, Old Iron Face, the Tar Monster,  the Highland Ghost and Loch Ness Monster, and a recording studio phantom that looks like a bad version of Paul Stanley in stage makeup. There are a few mediocre episodes, and this is only because of lackluster villains. The gang tends to travel abroad a lot, creating possibilities besides conventional haunted houses. I think Velma's 'new' voice is still nerdy and fine, just lower pitched, and I like Daphne's second voice better than her first. It's still just a gang of five; cousin Dum doesn't join until later seasons. This DVD is a worthwhile addition for hardcore Scooby fans. NOTE: You will NOT find other obscure favorites like the Demon Shark, Gator Ghoul, No-Face Zombie, or Ice-Cream Phantoms in this collection. They are on the Scooby Doo/Dynomutt Hour Complete Series DVD, which is really great. And you won't find the Viking Ghosts or that awesome funeral parlor vampire episode either; they're considered episodes of the Scooby Doo Show. My only gripe about the Season 3 DVD is its packaging; I think all episodes should be listed on the outside cover. Some Scooby fans will spot it in stores before doing an online search!

The 1978-1979 Saturday morning TV season saw the premiere of 16 new Scooby-Doo episodes. The ABC Saturday morning TV schedule for September 1978 was as follows:

.....08:00-08:30 AM EST Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!
.....08:30-09:00 AM EST Fangface
.....09:00-10:00 AM EST Challenge of the Super Friends
.....10:00-11:30 AM EST Scooby's All-Stars
.....11:30-12:00 PM EST The All-New Pink Panther Show

These new Scooby-Doo episodes began airing under the Scooby-Doo, Where Are You! show at 8:00 AM EST, using the original 1969 opening credits, just with all new shows. Yes, really! The 90 minute Scooby's All-Stars show was composed of a half hour of new and repeat episodes of the Laff-a-Lympics, a half hour of new and repeat episodes of Captain Caveman and the Teen Angels, and a half hour of repeat ONLY episodes of Scooby-Doo from the previous 1976-1977 and 1977-1978 seasons.

After only 9 weeks, the popular Challenge of the Super Friends show was expanded from 60 minutes to 90 minutes, adding an extra half hour of repeats from their 1977-1978 season. Thus, ABC shuffled it's Saturday morning TV schedule as follows:

.....08:00-09:30 AM EST Scooby's All-Stars
.....09:30-11:00 AM EST Challenge of the Super Friends
.....11:00-11:30 AM EST Fangface
.....11:30-12:00 PM EST The All-New Pink Panther Show

The remaining 7 new Scooby-Doo episodes then began airing during the half hour Scooby-Doo portion of the 90 minute Scooby's All-Stars show. This remained the status quo, and all 16 new Scooby-Doo episodes from this season were then repeated throughout the remainder of the season as part of Scooby's All-Stars.

What confuses everyone is that the 16 new episodes from this season, PLUS the 16 Scooby-Doo episodes from the 1976-1977 season of The Scooby-Doo/Dynomutt Hour, PLUS the 8 Scooby-Doo episodes from the 1977-1978 season of Scooby's All-Star Laff-a-Lympics (16 + 8 + 16 = 40 episodes in total) were re-packaged together as "The Scooby-Doo Show" for syndication repeats starting in 1980. So most folks only know these episodes from the syndication repeats airing on cable networks like Cartoon Network or Boomerang, and NOT from their original airings. It was NEVER called "The Scooby-Doo Show" during any of the original ABC Saturday morning airings.

Unfortunately, the DVD set is named and advertised as if it's the original airings of these 16 episodes. But they are NOT! The DVD set has the syndicated re-packaged versions with "The Scooby-Doo Show" opening and closing credits, and NOT the original Scooby-Doo, Where Are You! or Scooby's All-Stars opening and closing credits as they originally aired.

So, whether you think of these episodes as Scooby-Doo, Where Are You! Season 3, Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!: The Lost Episodes, Scooby's All-Stars, or even "The Scooby-Doo Show" Season 3, it is the COMPLETE, yes, COMPLETE 1978-1979 Saturday morning season of Scooby-Doo with the same 16 episodes, just with the syndicated re-packaged opening and closing credits. There are no missing episodes from this season set. If you are a fan of this late 70's era of Scooby-Doo, (just before the coming of Scrappy-Doo), you will greatly enjoy the 16 episodes on this set.

My only fear now is that when they get around to releasing the Hanna-Barbera animated DVD sets of, oh say, The Adventures of Gulliver, or even The Atom Ant Show, we're going to get the syndicated re-packaged version from "The Banana Splits and Friends Show"....

Review Forward: I know much of this has already been said, but I leave it in for consolidation purposes...

This is actually the third season of "The Scooby Doo Show" which ran from 1976-1978. This is NOT Season 3 of "Scooby Doo, Where Are You?", the original Scooby Doo series which initially aired for two seasons in 1969 and 1970. There never was a season 3 of "Scooby Doo, Where Are You" in 1970 or 1971.

NOTE, however, that according to animation expert Earl Kress, these 1978 episodes were the unofficial "third season" of "Scooby Doo, Where Are You!" released MUCH later, and utilizing the Original Series' 1969 opening intro/title & credits. It supposedly aired as "Where Are You?" on the East Coast from September through December 1978 before being incorporated into the "Scooby's All-Stars" show. This 1978 broadcast was canceled after "Who Was That Cat Creature I Saw You With Last Night?", and the remaining seven third-season episodes were aired during the "Scooby's All-Stars" block and revamped to use "The Scooby Doo Show" title/intro & credits for its subsequent airings in syndication.

This Season 3 DVD uses "The Scooby Doo Show" intro which starts "He's got it all together for a brand new show, Scooby Doo is here and away we go".

1969 and 1970 where the first 2 and only "Scooby Doo, Where are You?" seasons.  1973 Came the disappointment of the "Scooby Doo and Scrappy Doo Show", on Sat. mornings. Leaving all others to fall short of our high expectations.  The "Where are you" seasons started a whole new mystery genre in cartoons on Sat. mornings.  Does anyone remember, just to name a few, The Bufford Files, The Gallopping Ghost, Clue Club or the Chan Clan?  Hanna-Barbera at their best. From Wikipedia: "Season 3" (1978)
For more details on this topic, see The Scooby-Doo Show.
For the 1978-1979 television season, Hanna-Barbera produced sixteen episodes of a third season of Scooby-Doo, Where are You! for broadcast on ABC. These episodes follow the episodes of Scooby-Doo made in 1976 and 1977 for ABC, and are more similar to those episodes than the 1969-1971 originals except that Scooby-Dum, a semi-regular character from the 1976 and 1977 episodes, does not appear.

ABC began airing these episodes on Saturday mornings at 8:00 AM EST beginning in September 1978. The show was canceled in November 1978 after nine episodes; the remaining seven first-run episodes were broadcast during ABC's Scooby's All-Stars block at 10:00 AM, which was originally broadcasting reruns of the 1976 and 1977 episodes. These 1978 episodes have been aired in syndication as part of The Scooby-Doo Show since the 1980s, but are to be released on DVD under the title "'Scooby-Doo, Where are You!: The Complete Third Season.
